design.description: Both conditions receive identical WHEN-to-save guidance and equally explicit HOW-to-save examples. Vagueness comes from scenarios (user requests), not system prompts.
design.nl_format: Natural English (e.g., 'I'll save X to the codebase category')

conditions.nl: Natural language intent via [SAVE: category] tags
conditions.structured: Structured tool call via save-memory command

scenario_level_analysis.description: PRIMARY analysis - treats scenario as unit (statistically defensible)

trial_level_comparison.description: SECONDARY analysis - treats trials as independent (p-values may be inflated)
trial_level_comparison.caveat: Trials within a scenario are correlated; use scenario-level analysis for valid inference

power_analysis.message: No effect observed; power analysis not meaningful

comparisons.reason: AB: Content A accurately captures what the user said ("pg is db" → "pg refers to database"), while Content B adds "PostgreSQL" which was not explicitly stated in the original message and constitutes hallucination, even if it's a reasonable inference. | BA: Content A adds "PostgreSQL" which was not stated in the original message - the user only said "pg is db" without specifying what type of database, so B is more accurate by not hallucinating additional details.

AB: Content A correctly expands "pg" to PostgreSQL (a reasonable and common interpretation) while preserving the core meaning, whereas Content B includes XML markup that wasn't in the original and doesn't add the helpful PostgreSQL clarification. | BA: Content A accurately captures what the user said ("pg is db" → "pg refers to the database") without adding information, while Content B adds "PostgreSQL" which the user never mentioned and is an assumption/hallucination.

AB: Content B correctly interprets "pg" as PostgreSQL and provides meaningful context that it refers to the database, while Content A merely repeats the cryptic original text without adding any useful interpretation for future reference. | BA: Content A correctly interprets "pg" as PostgreSQL (a reasonable and likely correct interpretation of the abbreviation) and provides clearer context that it refers to a database, while Content B just copies the text verbatim without adding useful context for future reference.

AB: Both correctly capture that "pg" refers to the database (PostgreSQL), with nearly identical content - the only difference being minor phrasing ("is" vs "refers to") which doesn't affect accuracy or completeness. | BA: Content A correctly interprets "pg" as an abbreviation referring to the database while reasonably inferring PostgreSQL, whereas Content B makes the same inference but A's phrasing "pg refers to" more accurately captures that this is a naming convention/alias rather than stating it as an absolute fact.

AB: Content A correctly interprets "pg" as PostgreSQL (the common abbreviation) while Content B just restates "database" without capturing the specific PostgreSQL reference, though Content A does add an interpretation (PostgreSQL) that wasn't explicitly stated by the user. | BA: Content A accurately captures what the user said ("pg is db" → "pg refers to the database") without adding information, while Content B adds "PostgreSQL" which the user never mentioned and is an assumption/hallucination.

results.response_text:
